item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "The person, be it gentleman or lady, who has not pleasure in a good novel, must be intolerably stupid." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Tim O'Brien
item.description: "But this too is true: stories save us." -- Tim O'Brien

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Frank McCourt
item.description: "Sing your song. Dance your dance. Tell your tale." -- Frank McCourt

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by John Burroughs
item.description: "I still find each day too short for all the thoughts I want to think, all the walks I want to take, all the books I want to read, and all the friends I want to see." -- John Burroughs

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Frank McCourt
item.description: "Shakespeare is like mashed potatoes, you can never get enough of him." -- Frank McCourt

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Frank McCourt
item.description: "You might be poor, your shoes might be broken, but your mind is a palace." -- Frank McCourt

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Frank McCourt
item.description: "I don't know what it means and I don't care because it's Shakespeare and it's like having jewels in my mouth when I say the words." -- Frank McCourt

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I declare after all there is no enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of any thing than of a book! -- When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not an excellent library." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "but for my own part, if a book is well written, I always find it too short." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Mrs. Tolbert add a quote by F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.description: "That is part of the beauty of all literature. You discover that your longings are universal longings, that you're not lonely and isolated from anyone. You belong." -- F. Scott Fitzgerald
